100190, China. 1 North 2nd Street, Zhongguancun, Haidian District Beijing 100190 China The synthesis of cyclic carbonates via carbon-oxygen bond activation of vicinal-diols and linear carbonates via transesterification is significant, but the reaction mechanism remains unclear. Herein, we synthesized 1,2-butene carbonate (1,2-BC) from 1,2-butanediol (1,2-BDO) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) as a target reaction and investigated the relationship between different CeO2 crystal effects and acid-base sites. CeO2-rod exhibits more oxygen vacancies (Ce3 +-Ov), generating additional Ce3+ and O2- as Lewis acid and base sites, respectively, enhancing the activation of C-O and O-H bonds. CeO2-R exhibited high activity, achieving a space-time yield of up to 500 g1,2-BC·h−1·gcat −1 during 200 h long-term operation. Difficulty in adsorption of the active conformation due to the presence of competing adsorption, in situ DRIFTS revealed that the bridging butoxy-Ov of 1,2-BDO and the cis-cis monodentate adsorption conformation of DMC play a decisive role in the reaction. The presence of key intermediates that are difficult to capture was confirmed for the first time. Molecular dynamics simulations justify the proposed theory of dehydrocyclization of the intermediate hydroxy butylmethyl carbonate to 1,2-BC. The good generalizability of vicinal-diol substrate provides a reference and inspiration for synthesizing cyclic carbonates. Graphical Abstract Abbreviations DMC Dimethyl carbonate 1 2-BDO, 1,2-Butanediol 1 2-BC,1,2-butene carbonate HBMC hydroxy butyl methyl carbonate HEMC Hydroxyethyl methyl carbonate Keywords Cyclic carbonate Oxygen vacancy Acid-base Competitive adsorption Sustainability Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Cyclic carbonate is an important chemical and organic synthesis intermediate, widely used in high-energy lithium battery electrolytes, cosmetic additives, etc [1,2]. Recently, copolymers and aliphatic homopolymers with cyclic carbonate as basic units have attracted attention as biodegradable materials. As a typical example, 1,2-butene carbonate (1,2-BC) can be used as an electrolyte in lithium batteries, an important chemical for producing plasticizers, etc. Transesterification is an attractive method because it can feedstock bio-based diols, providing a green and sustainable pathway for the production of cyclic carbonates [3–6]. Various catalysts, such as hydrotalcite oxides, molecular sieves, alkaline earth metal oxides, and ionic liquids, have been reported in studies for synthesizing cyclic carbonates [7,8]. However, the transesterification route to synthesize cyclic carbonates still suffers from the problems of unclear acid-base functionality, difficult to capture intermediates, and competing adsorption of carbon-oxygen bonds. The key to synthesizing cyclic carbonates depends on the selective activation of the C-O bond and the vicinal-diol O-H bond in the carbonate, which poses a challenge to the design of catalysts. The rare earth cerium (Ce) element is often used as a catalyst in organic catalysis due to its unique acid-base and oxidation-reduction (Ce4+ ↔ Ce3+) properties, and the field of cerium-based catalysts has shown experienced explosive growth in recent years [9–11]. However, most acid-base characterization of cerium dioxide (CeO2) is performed in the polycrystalline state, where the surface structure is a complex mixture of various surface and structural defects, hindering further design and improvement. Over the past few decades, various synthesis strategies for CeO2 with controllable morphology and size have been discovered successively, such as the thermal decomposition [12] and electrochemical method, etc [13]. CeO2 with different morphologies such as ellipsoidal [14] and flower has been successfully synthesized [15]. The relationship between catalytically active sites and crystalline surfaces is gradually being investigated. CeO2 exhibits different properties in terms of surface stability and oxygen vacancy formation energy for different major exposed crystal facets such as (110), (100), and (111). CeO2 with a single exposed crystal facet helps to correlate the catalytic behavior more precisely. Adsorption of hydroxyl groups on the surface of CeO2 leads to different types of Ce-O species, i.e., on-top, bridged, and three-coordinate. The different Ce-O distributions depend on the surface structure of CeO2 and the number of defect sites carried [16,17]. The defect sites of nano-oxide materials have always been the focus of attention, and their coordination of unsaturated properties can effectively promote the activation and transformation of reactants [18]. The number and type of acid-base sites exhibit different dependence on the surface structure of CeO2. Therefore, it is important to understand the crystal interaction and acid-base properties of CeO2 under different exposed facets for further understanding of its catalytic behavior. Although intensive experimental and theoretical studies have been carried out for CeO2 catalysts, the mechanism of C-O and O-H bond activation mediated by surface acid-base sites and Ceδ+-O structures remains poorly understood. Here, the present work aims to explore the carbon-oxygen restructuring mechanism in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates by using the morphology of CeO2 nanorods (CeO2-R), CeO2 cubes (CeO2-C), and CeO2 octahedrons (CeO2-O) as catalysts and the transesterification of 1,2-butanediol (1,2-BDO) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) to synthesize 1,2-BC as a probe reaction. Kinetic investigation and multiple substrate explorations were carried out. The acid-basicity and surface defects of the catalyst were analyzed by Raman, EPR, and CO2/NH3-TPD. Optimal adsorption configurations of DMC and 1,2-BDO were identified through in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS). The reaction mechanism of 1,2-BDO and DMC on CeO2 surfaces was investigated and proposed using operando FTIR under transient conditions. Experimental results integrated with molecular dynamics simulations revealed the structure of elusive key intermediates. Furthermore, the interplay between CeO2 crystal facets, defects, and acid-base properties was uncovered, and the crystal facet-dependent catalytic behavior and valence bond reconfiguration mechanism in CeO2-catalyzed 1,2-BC synthesis were analyzed at the molecular level. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and catalyst preparation The Ce(NO3)3⋅6 H2O (99 %) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co, Ltd, NaOH (99 %), were purchased from Xilong Chemical Co, Ltd, dimethyl carbonate, ethylene glycol (99 %), 1,2-propanediol, glycerol (99 %), 1,2-butanediol (≥98 %), 1,3-butanediol (≥99.5 %), 1,3-Propanediol (≥99.5 %), 2,3-butanediol (≥98 %), 1,2-pentanediol (≥98 %), 1,2-hexanediol (≥98 %) and biphenyl (99 %) were purchased from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co, Ltd. The preparation methods were referred to previous reports, and the experimental scheme was appropriately improved (Supporting Information 1) [19,20]. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The morphology of all catalysts was investigated by a Zeiss Gemini 300 scanning electron microscope (SEM) under 30 kV accelerating voltage and a TF20 transmission electron microscope (TEM). X-ray diffraction (XRD) data of catalyst by Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffraction measurements (Cu-Ka). The microcrystal size of catalysts was calculated using the Debye-Scheler formula. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was obtained by Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument, corrected by C 1 s = 284.8 eV binding energy. Raman spectroscopy was tested on the HORIBA Scientific LabRAM HR Evolution spectrometer. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were recorded at room temperature on Bruker EMX plus device. The program temperature (TPD), Operando IR, and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) test details are in Supporting Information. The edge energy of the XANES spectrum was determined from the inflection point in the leading edge, that is, the maximum in the first derivative of the leading edge of the XANES spectra. The structural parameters were obtained by a least-squares fit in R space for the k3-weighted Fourier-transformed data using Artemis. 2.3 Catalytic test All transesterification reactions were carried out in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave. In a typical experimental procedure, nitrogen purges and replaces the gas in the reactor before the experiment begins. At the end of the reaction, the reaction product was separated, and the appropriate amount of supernatant was taken and added to the internal standard to configure the standard solution. The content of each substance was quantitatively analyzed by gas chromatography (AOC-20I PLUS, 30 m*0.32 mm*1 μm) equipped with a FID detector using ethanol as solvent. The SPL1 temperature was set to 260°C, the column temperature was set to 80°C, the retention time was 1 min and then the temperature was increased to 240°C at a rate of 15 min/°C, and the retention time was again 1 min. The FID detector temperature was set to 250°C. The conversion of 1,2-BDO, and the selectivity of 1,2-BC are calculated as follows: (1) Conv . of 1 , 2 − BDO = n initial 1 , 2 − BDO − n residual 1 , 2 − BDO n initial 1 , 2 − BDO × 100 % (2) Sel . of 1 , 2 − BC = n 1 , 2 − BC n initial 1 , 2 − BDO × Conv . of 1 , 2 − BDO × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1(a b c) shows a wide size distribution of SEM and TEM images of CeO2-R, with an average size of 29.3 nm. There are many truncations on the surface, indicating the existence of abundant coordination unsaturated defects [21]. Furthermore, HRTEM and FFT analyses indicate that CeO2-R has polycrystal properties with predominantly bare lattice streaks, which are attributed to the (100), (110), and (111) crystal facets of the fluorite crystal phase structure. It exhibits a one-dimensional linear structure with optimal growth along the (110) direction [16,22]. According to Fig. 1(d e f), the average size of CeO2-C is 13.1 nm, with side lengths ranging from 7.6 to 23.0 nm. It not only has a small size distribution but also has a perfect cube shape. The lattice fringes are attributed to the (100) crystal facet of CeO2-C and grow mainly along the (100) direction [19,23]. Fig. 1(g h i) shows SEM and TEM images of CeO2-O, with an average side length of 663.7 nm. Obviously, the CeO2-O has smoother and flatter surfaces, perfect geometric shapes, and clear edges, indicating that the octahedron is well-crystallized and has no obvious surface defects. It mainly exposes structurally stable low-energy crystal facet (111). Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) results further showed that CeO2-R reached a specific surface area of 73 g and a total pore volume of 0.37 g. In comparison, the surface-flattened CeO2-O had a specific surface area of only 4 g and a pore volume as low as 0.009 g. The high defect site content of CeO2-R was further confirmed. 3.1.1 Catalytic activity To explore the differences in the catalytic performance of CeO2, the three catalysts prepared were tested for the synthesis of 1,2-BC ( Fig. 2a). First, the reaction without a catalyst yielded negligible 1,2-BC (<1 %), confirming the necessity of a catalyst. Notably, CeO2-R exhibited superior catalytic activity, achieving 90.8 % conversion of 1,2-BDO with a space-time yield of 125 g1,2-BC·h−1·gcat −1 (the optimal equilibrium value is 500 g1,2-BC·h−1·gcat −1, 130 °C, 0.5 wt%, DMC/1,2-BDO = 3:1, 30 min) (Figs. S3-6). The CeO2-C showed moderate performance (57.9 % conversion, 80 g1,2-BC·h−1·gcat −1, whereas CeO2-O was nearly inactive (1.20 % conversion, 4 g1,2-BC·h−1·gcat −1). Catalyst stability is critical for practical applications. To evaluate the long-term stability of the key parameters of interest. Therefore, to further test the long-term stability of CeO2-R, 1,2-BC synthesis was carried out using a fixed-bed reactor under a continuous-feed experimental environment, and the sample tube was filled with 1.0 g of 40–60 mesh catalyst. A mixed DMC/1,2-BDO solution was configured and transported to the inside of the reactor via an advection pump. The reaction solution was collected at the bottom of the reactor and sampled every 4–8 h interval. The products were diluted with ethanol and then quantitatively analyzed by gas chromatography. Remarkably, even after 200 h of operation, the selectivity for 1,2-BC remained > 99.9 %, with a stable yield of ∼95.0 % (Fig. 2b). Kinetic studies were conducted to more accurately assess the catalytic activity of CeO2-R, CeO2-C, and CeO2-O. The chemical reaction rate constant (k), frequency factor (A), and reaction activation energy ( E a ) of different catalysts were determined through kinetic studies (Fig. S8-9). The results showed that the reaction rates of CeO2-R and CeO2-C increased rapidly with the increase in temperature, and the apparent activation energies were 38.55 ± 3.5 and 58.10 ± 2.9 kJ·mol−1 (Figs. 2c, 2d), respectively. However, when CeO2-O was used as the catalyst for the reaction, the conversion of 1,2-BDO was very low even at elevated temperatures, and the apparent activation energy was nearly impossible to calculate, suggesting that the activation energy required to overcome the potential barrier of the CeO2-O reaction was tremendous and detrimental to the reaction. Compared with the catalysts used in the same type of cyclic carbonate synthesis, CeO2-R exhibits clear advantages of lower activation energy and higher space-time yield (Table S2). To further study the significant difference in the catalytic activity of CeO2 exposed to different crystal surfaces, additional studies were carried out. Fig. 3a shows the XRD patterns of catalysts. All the samples exhibit the cubic crystal fluorite phase structure (PDF# 43–1002, space group Fm3m (225)). The reflection peak at 2θ of 28.6°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.3°, 59.1°, 69.4°,76.7°, 79.1°, and 88.3° correspond to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), (420), and (422) crystal facets of CeO2. The results showed that the CeO2 phase structure was formed after hydrothermal roasting and calcination. It is observed that CeO2-O has a strong and sharp diffraction peak, followed by CeO2-C and CeO2-R, indicating that the crystallinity of CeO2 follows the order of CeO2-O > CeO2-C > CeO2-R. The weak and broad diffraction peaks mean that CeO2-R has the worst crystallinity and higher structure disorder and may result in more defect sites. The average grain size is calculated as CeO2-R (9.1 nm), CeO2-C (23.6 nm), CeO2-O (25.2 nm) according to the full width at half maximum (FWHM), and Debye-Scherrer equation of single-phase diffraction peak of (111) [24]. The calculated lattice constants a and the ordering are CeO2-R (0.5409 nm) < CeO2-C (0.5412 nm) < CeO2-O (0.5422 nm), which are different from the standard reported values CeO2 (0.5411 nm) [25]. This discrepancy can be attributed to the difference in ionic radius (rCe3+ = 1.14 Å，rCe4+ = 0.94 Å), lattice expansion is usually observed when the proportion of partially reduced Ce3+ increases [26], and the lattice shrinkage due to the increase in the surface/volume ratio as the microcrystal size decreases [25,27]. The electronic structure and coordination environment of CeO2 catalysts were further investigated by X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy. Fig. 3d displays the Ce K-edge XANES curves of CeO2-R, CeO2-C, and CeO2-O, as well as the commercial CeO2 and Ce2O3 samples used as standard samples. It is further found that there is a main peak at 1.89 Å, which is attributed to the Ce-O path, and at 3.62 Å to the Ce-O-Ce scattering path (Fig. 3b). This result was further confirmed by the high-resolution R-space and k-space CeO2 spectra obtained by wavelet transform EXAFS (WT-EXAFS) (Fig. 3g1-g3, Fig. S14). The coexistence of Ce3+/Ce4+ was confirmed by the presence of two white-line edge absorption peaks at 5730.9 eV and 5738.4 eV, corresponding to the transition from the Ce 2p3/2 state to the unoccupied Ce 5d state with 4f1 or 4f0 end states. As shown in Figs. 3e-3f, the Ce K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES) curves lie between CeO2 and Ce2O3, indicating that the oxidation state of Ce lies between + 4 and + 3. The R-space extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra, obtained by Fourier transform in k-space, show that the intensity of the CeO2-R, CeO2-C, and CeO2-O shell signal is weakened compared to the commercial CeO2, and CeO2-R is located at the lowest intensity, suggesting that it has the highest concentration of oxygen vacancies (Ov). The EXAFS fitting curves show that the coordination number of the Ce atoms with the O atoms is 3.4 (CeO2-R), 4.1 (CeO2-C), and 4.8 (CeO2-O), respectively (Table S1). These results confirm that CeO2-R has the highest content of Ov, and combined with the catalytic performance in Fig. 2a, the presence of Ov may be a key factor in enhancing catalytic activity. CeO2-R, CeO2-C, and CeO2-O all exhibit type IV adsorption-desorption isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops (Fig. S2), indicating that the three morphologies of CeO2 have abundant mesoporous structures [28]. As shown in Table 1, it can be concluded that CeO2-R has the largest specific surface area and pore volume with smaller grain size, which may have more active sites exposed, favoring mass transfer and electron transfer. CeO2-R displays a bimodal mesoporous distribution with a narrow peak centered at 2.47 nm and a broad peak centered at 15.6 nm, with a small number of large pore structures. This facilitates the diffusion and migration of reactants and products in the corresponding catalysts, thus promoting the catalytic performance [29]. The Ov content of the three CeO2 was further analyzed using Raman spectroscopy. All three catalysts exhibit a strong peak at the position of 462 cm−1, which is the main triple degenerate F2 g mode in the fluorite phase of CeO2 and is considered as the symmetric stretching vibration of Ce-O (Fig. 3e) [26,30]. The weak band at 590 cm−1 is attributed to the defect-induction mode ID of CeO2, which is seen as a fingerprint peak with oxygen defects on the CeO2 surface [31]. It is further known that the quantification of surface Ov concentration can be obtained by using the integrated area ratio (ID/F2 g) for bands 590 and 462 cm−1 [32,33] [18,34]. Calculations show that the rod structure has the highest concentration of surface Ov ( Table 2). The EPR spectrum of CeO2 is shown in Fig. 3f. The strong single-line EPR signal at g = 2.003 indicates the highest concentration of Ov on the CeO2-R surface [35], further validating the Raman and XAFS results. Characterization of substance content and oxygen defects by XPS is a common tool in catalytic studies. In the Ce 3d spectrum, eight deconvoluted peaks are observed, v (917.08 eV), v'' (908.18 eV), v''' (899.88 eV), u (897.68 eV), u'' (889.68 eV), and u''' (883.08 eV) belong to Ce4+, v′ (902.98 eV) and u′ (886.28 eV) belong to Ce3+ ( Fig. 4b), indicating that Ce3+ and Ce4+ coexist [36,37]. The results reveal that the Ce3+ content of CeO2-R, CeO2-C, and CeO2-O is 23.03 %, 19.38 %, and 8.06 %, respectively. CeO2-R has more oxygen vacancy defects, which is consistent with the theoretically predicted vacancy formation energy order of (110) < (100) < (111) [38]. The O 1 s XPS spectrum further confirms the presence of three oxygen species on the CeO₂ surface (Fig. 4c). The binding energy of 531–533 eV is attributed to surface adsorbed oxygen (denoted as Oα), 529–531 eV is attributed to lattice oxygen (denoted as Oβ), and larger than 533 eV is attributed to surface hydroxyl groups (OH) [39]. The quantization results of the Oα/(Oα+Oβ) ratio were ranked in the order CeO2-R (75.87 %) > CeO2-C (55.82 %) > CeO2-O (40.48 %) (Table 2). Surface oxygen species with higher mobility are more active in catalytic reactions than lattice oxygen, and the increase of surface oxygen facilitates reaction activation and friendly adsorption of materials, accelerating the reaction [40,41]. Surface acidity and basicity are important factors affecting the formation of cyclic carbonate, the surface acidity and basicity of CeO2 were measured by CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD (Figs. 4e, 4f). The deconvolution of the CO2-TPD profile into three peaks in the temperature intervals of 50–200 °C, 200–400 °C, and 400–800 °C are attributed to the desorption of weak, moderate, and strong basic sites of CO2, respectively [42,43]. Basic hydroxyl groups and basic surface oxygen are usually present on metal oxides, often distinguished by the different carbonate species. The quantization results obtained by desorption are shown in Table 3. CeO2-R had the largest number of sites in different basic sites, and the number of weakly basic sites significantly differed from CeO2-C and CeO2-O. In contrast, the number of moderately basic and strongly basic sites on the surface of the three catalysts was not significantly different. However, should note that compared with CeO2-C, CeO2-O had the same medium and strong basic sites, but CeO2-O is hardly catalytically active. Therefore, it can be further found that the carbonate species formed by different surface structures of CeO2 show different degrees of dependence in terms of number and species. Combined with the experimental results (Fig. 2a), it is inferred that the existence of weakly basic sites plays an obvious role in improving the catalytic effect of 1,2-BC. The desorption spectral trend and acid quantification results of NH3-TPD follow a similar pattern to that of CO2-TPD (Fig. 4f). The three forms of CeO2 exhibit different numbers of weak and strong acidic sites. The number of weakly and moderately acidic sites differs significantly, with the number of weakly acidic sites on the surface of CeO2-R being four times higher than that of CeO2-C and more than seven times higher than that of CeO2-O, which is similar to the ratio of the results for the weakly basic sites. The number of moderately acidic sites on the surface was much higher than that of CeO2-C and CeO2-O. However, there was little difference in the number of strongly acidic sites on the CeO2 catalysts, where the number of strongly acidic sites on CeO2-C and CeO2-O was similar. The acidity of CeO2 is related to cerium ion, CeO2-R has the most Ce3+ and abundant oxygen defects. Although Ce3+ is a weak Lewis acid, it exhibits significant acidity in more ligand-unsaturated states. In summary, it can be concluded that the acid-base properties of the CeO2 surface strongly depend on the exposed crystalline surface of the catalyst, and that the presence of Lewis acids (Ce3+) facilitates the efficient synthesis of 1,2-BC. Combining the relationship between acid-base properties and catalytic performance of different CeO2, it can be concluded that CeO2-R enriched in acid-base sites is more favorable for the carbonylation reaction to generate cyclic carbonates. The high correlation between different surface acid-base properties and catalytic activity of CeO2 (Fig. 4d, Table 3) indicates that weakly acidic and basic sites play a more important role in promoting the carbonylation to generate the 1,2-BC reaction than the moderately acidic and strongly acidic sites. 3.2 Reaction mechanism To directly investigate the differences in the adsorption and configuration between CeO2 interacting with DMC and 1,2-BDO on different crystal facets, we tracked the surface information of three catalysts using in situ DRIFTS under varying temperatures and atmospheres. Pure 1,2-BDO and DMC adsorption experiments on different CeO2 surfaces were conducted at room temperature to observe the changes in IR spectra ( Figs. 5-6). The special coordination environment of cerium cations leads to the presence of 1,2-BDO adsorption conformations on the surface of Ce atoms in three states: on-top butoxy, bridging butoxy, bridging butoxy-Ov, and three-coordinate butoxy [44,45]. The vibrational configuration of C-O is strongly sensitive to surface coordination and is often used to determine the conformation of surface adsorption. After adsorption of 1,2-BDO for 30 min, the 1093 and 1081 cm−1 vibrational peaks appeared in the C-O stretching vibrational region on the surface of CeO2-R (110), which were attributed to the on-top butoxy adsorption conformation and the bridging butoxy adsorption conformation, respectively. The presence of the triple-coordinated butoxylate adsorption conformation was not found (Fig. 5a) [46,47]. The broader characteristic peak at 3370 cm−1 may be due to hydrogen bonding between the hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface and the alcohol hydroxyl groups, forming water-type species on the CeO2 surface [48,49]. The adsorption conformation of 1,2-BDO on the surface of the CeO2-C (100) is dominated by the bridging butoxy (1067 cm−1), with the on-top butoxy conformation showing weak adsorption occupation at 1100 cm−1 (Fig. 5b). This is due to the different degrees of unsaturation of the cerium cation coordination, with (111) being 7-coordinated and (110) being 6-coordinated, while (100) is usually considered a polar surface and requires the removal of half of the surface oxygen to stabilize the polar surface, and thus is more likely to form bridged structures with a higher percentage of bridged species [50,51]. Compared to the adsorption results on the (100) and (110) surfaces, a weaker bridging butoxy adsorption conformation was found on the CeO2-O (111) surface only at 1073 cm−1, the on-top butoxy and three-coordinated butoxy adsorption conformations were not found (Fig. 5c). This suggests that the adsorption conformation of butoxy is related to the content of defective sites on the surface of CeO2. Raman, XAFS, and XPS characterization results indicate that the highly crystalline (111) surface has a small number of Ov and thus adsorbs only a very small amount of 1,2-BDO. The lack of surface defects hinders the surface reaction, which is consistent with the adsorption results. Rapid desorption of aqueous species from the three CeO2 surfaces was observed when heated to higher temperatures (433 K). The adsorption intensity of on-top butoxy at 1093 cm−1 gradually decreases on the rod-like (110) surface, indicating that the on-top butoxy is weakly adsorbed and poorly stabilized (Fig. 5b). Meanwhile, the bridging butoxy-Ov adsorption conformation at 1046 cm−1 began to appear with the decrease of the on-top butoxy adsorption conformation. Further, the on-top butoxy is poorly stabilized during desorption on the surface of cube-like (100), which is fully desorbed at 313 K (Fig. 5d). The on-top butoxy is not stabilized during desorption on the surface of (100). The bridging butoxy adsorption conformation on the (100) surface was stabilized during the warming process with an increasing percentage, and the cleavage peak appeared at 1074 cm−1. Unlike the change in the desorption process of (110), the (100) surface showed a three-coordinated butoxy adsorption conformation at 1019 cm−1 with increasing temperature. On the inactive octahedral (111) surface, the bridging butoxy at 1073 cm−1 desorbs rapidly with increasing temperature, accompanied by the appearance of weak on-top butoxy and bridging butoxy-Ov conformations (Fig. 5 f). This suggests that the lack of Ov on the (111) surface may lead to difficulties in 1,2-BDO adsorption. Combining the catalytic activity performance of the three CeO2 surfaces and the in situ DRIFTS results of 1,2-BDO on the three crystalline facets in Fig. 2a, it can be concluded that the occupation of bridging butoxy-Ov adsorption conformation is favorable for the promotion of transesterification. Unlike the adsorption results for 1,2-BDO, the difference in adsorption of DMC on the three CeO2 surfaces was more significant (Fig. 6). The sensitivity of the CO bond to the different coordination surfaces facilitates the determination of the type of adsorption of DMC on the three CeO2 surfaces, which exhibit three IR bands. The CO bidentate adsorption conformation of DMC at 1780 cm−1 is attributed to the red-shifted CO absorption peak of DMC due to the quaternary structure formed in the bidentate adsorption process [52]. The peaks at 1766 and 1750 cm−1 are attributed to the cis-cis monodentate and cis-trans monodentate adsorption conformation of DMC, respectively. The positively charged cerium ions weaken the energy of the CO bond, resulting in a blue shift of the absorption peak [53]. On the Ov-rich CeO2-R (110) surface, we observed three conformations of bidentate adsorption (1780 cm−1), cis-cis monodentate adsorption (1766 cm−1), and cis-trans monodentate adsorption (1750 cm−1) conformations that appeared sequentially at room temperature with increasing time (Fig. 6a) [54]. Of these, the bidentate adsorption and the cis-trans monodentate adsorption conformations were predominantly occupied. The presence of three adsorption conformations was also found on the CeO2-C (100) surface, differing from the adsorption results on the (110) surface where the cis-trans monodentate adsorption conformation was less occupied (Fig. 6c). In contrast to the adsorption results on the CeO2-R and CeO2-C surfaces (Fig. 6e), only a strong bidentate adsorption conformation (1780 cm−1) and a weak cis-cis monodentate adsorption conformation (1766 cm−1) were observed on the surface of CeO2-O (111) with the least Ov. The coverage of bidentate adsorption conformation is dominant, and there is no cis-trans monodentate adsorption conformation is observed. The changes in the desorption of DMC on the three CeO2 were further observed. We observed that the bidentate and cis-trans monodentate adsorption conformations on the highly active (110) surface decreased significantly with increasing temperature. Notably, the cis-trans monodentate adsorption conformation completely disappeared at 388 K, suggesting its relatively weak adsorption strength. The bidentate adsorption conformation at 1780 cm−1 was completely desorbed when the temperature reached 473 K. Meanwhile, the occupation of the cis-cis monodentate adsorption conformation at 1766 cm−1 increased significantly. This suggests that both adsorption conformations shifted to the cis-cis monodentate adsorption conformation, which may be the active adsorption conformation that is more favorable for the activation of DMC (Fig. 6b). Similar desorption phenomena were observed on the less catalytically active (100) surface, but unlike the (110) surface, the partially untransformed bidentate and cis-trans monodentate adsorption conformations still existed even at 473 K. This indicates that the bidentate adsorption conformation and cis-trans monodentate adsorption conformation adsorb more stably under the special coordination environment on the surface of (100), and the transition to the cis-cis monodentate adsorption conformation is more difficult to realize, which may act as a competing adsorption conformation occupying the active site and hindering the reaction (Fig. 6d). In contrast to the changes of (110) and (100), the adsorption conformation dominated by the bidentate adsorption on the inactive (111) surface did not show any significant change even at 473 K, and was still mainly occupied by the bidentate adsorption conformation (Fig. 6 f). The speculation that the bidentate adsorption conformation hinders the reaction is thus verified. Combining the adsorption and desorption results and the catalytic performances in Fig. 2a, it can be concluded that the cis-cis monodentate adsorption conformation of the CO bond is favorable for promoting the activation of DMC, whereas the weakly adsorbed cis-trans monodentate adsorption conformation and the overly adsorbed bidentate adsorption conformation, acting as competing adsorption conformations, will hinder the transesterification reaction. In summary, the (110) surface with abundant Ov is more favorable for modulating the adsorption strength of different conformations, shifting the low-activity adsorption conformations to the high-activity bridging butoxy-Ov and cis-cis monodentate adsorption conformations, and facilitating the transesterification for the highly efficient synthesis of 1,2-BC. On the contrary, the (111) surface with a very low content of Ov generates more competing adsorption conformations, which occupy the catalytic active sites and hinder transesterification. Based on our findings on the synthesis of cyclic carbonate, we proposed a reaction path for the formation of 1,2-BC by catalyzing 1,2-BDO and DMC under the action of CeO2 ( Fig. 7b) [20,55]. Firstly, 1,2-BDO and DMC are adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst. In the presence of CeO2, the primary alcohol group of 1,2-BDO is dissociated and activated on the catalyst surface and dehydrogenated to form the butoxy anion. The butoxy anion is further activated as a nucleophile, attacking the carbonyl group of DMC and simultaneously removing a molecule of methanol to produce the intermediate (hydroxy butyl methyl carbonate, HBMC). The secondary alcohol group is then activated as a nucleophile to attack the carbonyl group of DMC, and the second methanol molecule is formed while a stable five-membered ring structure is formed through intramolecular rearrangement. The adsorption of 1,2-BDO was constructed on the (110) crystal facet, and the electron density analysis was calculated by the crystal orbital Hamiltonian population (-COHP). The -COHP results show that the C-O bond of 1,2-BDO does not undergo significant change after adsorption, while not only is the bonding occupancy of electrons in the O-H bond significantly reduced, but there is also a significant anti-bonding occupancy, which indicates that the O-H bond is greatly weakened (Fig. 7c). The above electronic density of states results indicate that the molecules undergo decomposition via the de-hydrogenation mechanism rather than the de-hydroxylation mechanism, and the relevant density of states integral results are shown in Table S3. However, HBMC is difficult to detect and is often thought to exist only at low temperatures and for short periods [56]. To verify the plausibility of the existence of HBMC, we attempted to use Operando Fourier Transform Infrared (Operando FTIR) characterization to track the changes in the transesterification (Fig. 7a and Fig. S16). The peaks at 914 and 1455 cm−1 are attributed to the C-C skeleton vibration and -CH3 deformation vibration of DMC, respectively. The peaks at 908 and 1785 cm−1 are attributed to the C-C skeleton vibration and CO stretching vibration of 1,2-BC, and 1060 cm−1 is attributed to the symmetric stretching vibration of C-O. The change in peak value corresponds with the trend of 3D tracking. In addition, instantaneous monitoring results using CeO2-C and CeO2-O as catalysts are shown in Fig. S17-18). From the results of Operando FTIR spectroscopy, it was found that CeO2-C (Fig. 6b1-b3) is less active and CeO2-O (Fig. 6c1-c3) is almost inactive compared to CeO2-R, which was consistent with the in situ DRIFTS results. These results show that the difference in catalyst activity does not change the reaction path leading to 1,2-BC, but rather the difference in activity. The HBMC model was constructed on the surface of (110), and the stability of the intermediate was calculated using molecular dynamics simulations within 5 picoseconds, which revealed an obvious secondary dehydrogenation process, further proving the accuracy of the proposed reaction mechanism (Supporting video clip). Since HBMC could not be detected in the reaction, HEMC (intermediate of Ethylene carbonate) with a purity of more than 95 % was customized as an intermediate probe reaction, considering the complexity of the HBMC structure. The reaction of HEMC as a single reactant with CeO2-R yielded ethylene carbonate with a selectivity greater than 99 %, which for the first time experimentally confirmed the correctness of the proposed intermediate (Fig. S19-20). 3.3 Recyclability The catalyst was recovered and characterized after 200 h of use (Fig. S21-S23). The results show that CeO2-R still retains the pure cubic crystal fluorite phase structure, demonstrating good structural stability. Due to the adhesion of organic matter after long-term use, the average particle size increased slightly (from 9.1 to 9.4 nm). Additionally, the Oα content decreased from 75.8 % to 69.3 % (Fig. S22 & Table S4). Combined with the reaction results, the surface adsorptive oxygen plays a key role in the adsorption and activation of species. It can be found that the original medium and strong basic sites of CeO2-R disappeared, and a strong basic site appeared at 750 ℃. The strong acid site disappeared, and a new acidic site appeared at 400 ℃. Interestingly, the weak acid and weak base sites on the CeO2-R surface remained almost unchanged. Combined with the results of the long-cycle experiments, this precisely demonstrates that the weak acid and weak base sites on the surface of CeO2-R play a decisive role in the reaction, and the changes in the medium-strong sites have less influence on the catalytic performance. 3.4 Substrate scope Several typical cyclic carbonates including ethylene carbonate, propylene carbonate, glycerol carbonate, etc., are widely used as chemical raw materials and organic synthesis intermediates. Therefore, to explore the application and limitations of CeO2-R in the synthesis of cyclic carbonate. Different kinds of vicinal-diols were used as substrates ( Table 4). It can be seen that the yield of cyclic carbonate exceeds 96.0 %. It shows that CeO2-R can still maintain excellent catalytic performance in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates other than 1,2-BC. In addition, the catalytic effect of the synthesis of using meta-diol (1,3-BDO) into six-membered cyclic carbonates was also studied (Entry 5). However, the selectivity of 1,3-BC is only 82.9 %, which is due to the need to overcome more entropy effects in the six-membered ring formation process [57]. Exposure of the (110) crystalline surface of CeO2-R with oxygen-rich defects, greatly reduces the reaction activation energy for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates and has good general applicability in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of CeO2 catalysts with different morphologies were successfully synthesized and studies such as Ov and acid-base properties were carried out in the catalytic synthesis of the 1,2-BC. The space-time yield of 1,2-BC reached a space-time yield of 500 g1,2-BC·h−1·gcat −1, with stability of more than 200 h. The kinetic study found that the apparent activation energy of CeO2-R was 38.55 ± 3.5 kJ·mol−1, and that CeO2-C was 58.10 ± 2.9 kJ·mol−1. The abundant oxygen vacancies on the CeO2-R surface generate more Ce3+ and adsorbed oxygen, acting as Lewis acid centers and Lewis base centers to promote the activation of C-O and O-H bonds, respectively. The acid-base properties of the CeO2 surface are strongly dependent on the exposed crystal facet. Hydrogen atoms were found to be produced by O-H bond breaking during the de-methanol process by Operando FTIR spectroscopy and -COHP analysis. The existence of HBMC intermediates was demonstrated for the first time experimentally, and molecular dynamics simulation calculations proved that the intermediate dehydrogenated protons tend to synthesize 1,2-BC. In situ DRIFTS results show that the adsorption patterns of butoxy and carbonyl groups of the reactants are related not only to the coordination states of cerium atoms but also to the number of surface defects. The bridging butoxy-Ov of the hydroxyl group on 1,2-BDO and the cis-cis monodentate adsorption of the carbonyl group of DMC as the active adsorption conformations play a decisive role in the synthesis of 1,2-BC reactions. At the same time, CeO2-R has shown excellent universal application in the synthesis of various vicinal-diol and meta-diol substrates into cyclic carbonates. By studying the reactivity changes of CeO2 crystalline facets, guiding catalyst design for cyclic carbonate synthesis. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis of cyclic carbonates via carbon-oxygen bond activation of vicinal-diols and linear carbonates via transesterification is significant, but the reaction mechanism remains unclear. Herein, we synthesized 1,2-butene carbonate (1,2-BC) from 1,2-butanediol (1,2-BDO) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) as a target reaction and investigated the relationship between different CeO2 crystal effects and acid-base sites. CeO2-rod exhibits more oxygen vacancies (Ce3 +-Ov), generating additional Ce3+ and O2- as Lewis acid and base sites, respectively, enhancing the activation of C-O and O-H bonds. CeO2-R exhibited high activity, achieving a space-time yield of up to 500 g1,2-BC·h−1·gcat −1 during 200 h long-term operation. Difficulty in adsorption of the active conformation due to the presence of competing adsorption, in situ DRIFTS revealed that the bridging butoxy-Ov of 1,2-BDO and the cis-cis monodentate adsorption conformation of DMC play a decisive role in the reaction. The presence of key intermediates that are difficult to capture was confirmed for the first time. Molecular dynamics simulations justify the proposed theory of dehydrocyclization of the intermediate hydroxy butylmethyl carbonate to 1,2-BC. The good generalizability of vicinal-diol substrate provides a reference and inspiration for synthesizing cyclic carbonates.
